description:

event_name: John A. Pople Lecture in Theoretical and Computational Chemistry
description:
The John A. Pople Lecture in Theoretical and Computational Chemistry is a tribute to Pople’s enduring legacy. Renowned for his groundbreaking contributions to quantum chemistry, he shared the 1998 Nobel Prize for his remarkable achievements.
Krishnan Raghavachari joined Bell Laboratories as a research scientist in 1981 and later received the Distinguished Researcher Award in 1987. He joined Indiana University as a professor of chemistry in 2002 and was appointed a distinguished professor in 2014.
A co-author of more than 450 publications in the fields of chemistry, physics, biochemistry and materials science, his papers have been cited more than 80,000 times.
Learn more and register at https://events.mcs.cmu.edu/pople/
Sponsored by the Department of Chemistry

event_name: Finding Your Safe Space: The Power of Chosen Family in Allyship and Acceptance
location:
5 - 6 p.m.
Simmons Auditorium B, Tepper School of Business
description:
Ryan’s keynote will explore the transformative concept of “chosen family” — the friends and communities who provide vital support and acceptance beyond one’s biological family. Drawing from his personal journey as a Black, Millennial and Queer individual, Ryan will share how his upbringing in the conservative South and his time at Howard University shaped his search for a “chosen family” that allowed him to break free from societal expectations and find emotional and social support both on campus and in the wider world.
This event promises to resonate deeply with anyone seeking a sense of belonging or navigating their own identities. Ryan’s message of allyship, inclusion and the power of self-expression offers hope and inspiration to students from all backgrounds, particularly those passionate about the arts, advocacy and those beginning their journey in college. His story serves as a beacon for resilience, encouraging everyone to find their voice, cultivate their “why,” and embrace their uniqueness as a superpower.
Learn more and register: https://www.cmu.edu/title-ix/education-and-training/ryanjamaalswain.html

description:
Discover cutting-edge research in multiple fields and learn how AI research is being conducted to benefit society in many ways. See demonstrations of AI research in robotics, education, agriculture, physical sciences, weather and many other areas — and how we make ethical decisions about the use of AI.
Connect with 25 AI Institutes and partners and engage with their work.
Watch interactive panel discussions with AI and industry experts.
Network with 200+ attendees, researchers, and industry leaders.
Hear From Thought Leaders in AI Research:
Remarks from Carnegie Mellon University President Farnam Jahanian
Panel on Innovations in Generative AI Research & Use-Inspired Solutions
About the AI Institutes
The National Science Foundation and the U.S. Department of Agriculture-NIFA began establishing AI Institutes in 2020 to serve as national nexus points for collaborative AI efforts spanning higher education institutions, federal agencies, industry, and nonprofits/foundations. These 25 AI Institutes will showcase their research at AI Institutes Expo Day. To learn more about all 25 AI Institutes, visit the AIVO website at aiinstitutes.org.
This event is free and open to the public.
Learn more and register at https://na.eventscloud.com/website/65731/

event_name: Python for All: Democratizing Coding Mastery With AI Chatbot Support
description:
Using Python as our teaching tool, participants will acquire skills that are transferable to other programming languages. We will explore how AI chatbots can be invaluable resources for understanding, writing, and refining code, as well as for facilitating transitions between different coding languages.
Workshop attendees will:
AI Fundamentals: Understand key concepts and terminology related to generative AI.
Practical Application: Use generative AI as a programming assistant to enhance coding efficiency, troubleshoot errors, and tackle projects with greater confidence.
Critical Evaluation: Develop the ability to assess the accuracy, reliability, and usefulness of AI-generated code and solutions.
Ethical and Practical Evaluation: Examine the ethical implications of generative AI, recognizing its strengths, weaknesses, biases, limitations, and potential for misuse.
Adaptability and Continuous Learning: Cultivate skills to continuously adapt to advancements in AI technology.
Registration required: https://cmu.libcal.com/event/12813891

event_name: Human and Machine: Evolving Military Strategies in the Age of AI and Robotics
description:
The CMIST Scientists & Strategists speaker series brings together scientists and engineers with strategists and policymakers, fostering dynamic, in-person discussions that bridge the gap between research and real-world applications.
Moderated by CMIST Director Audrey Kurth Cronin, panelists Dr. T.X. Hammes and Dr. Jeff Schneider will explore how military strategies must evolve to keep pace with technological innovations, highlighting the balance between cutting-edge robotics and the human element in modern conflict. Don’t miss this chance to gain a deeper understanding of the dynamics between technology and human agency in the shifting nature of armed conflict.
Registration is required.
About Our Speakers
Dr. T.X. Hammes is a distinguished fellow at the National Defense University’s Center for Strategic Research and adjunct professor at Georgetown. He earned his B.S. from the U.S. Naval Academy and holds a Masters of Historical Research and a Doctorate in Modern History from Oxford University. A distinguished graduate of the Canadian National Defence College, he has published three books: Deglobalization and International Security; The Sling and the Stone: On War in the 21st Century; and Forgotten Warriors: The 1st Provisional Marine Brigade, the Corps’ Ethos, and the Korean War.
Prior to his retirement from active duty, Dr. Hammes served 30 years in the Marine Corps to include command of an intelligence battalion, an infantry battalion, and the Chemical Biological Response Force. His areas of expertise include the future of conflict, the changing character of war, military strategy, operational concepts, and insurgency.
Dr. Jeff Schneider is a research professor in the Carnegie Mellon University School of Computer Science, where his research is on machine learning for autonomous systems. He has more than 20 years of experience developing, publishing and applying machine learning algorithms in government, science and industry. He has hundreds of publications and routinely gives invited talks and tutorials on the subject.
Schneider is also an entrepreneur. He was a founding member of Uber’s Advanced Technologies Group and spent three years helping to build their self-driving car program. Before that, he developed a machine learning-based CNS drug discovery system and commercialized it during two years as PsychoGenics’ Chief Informatics Officer. Earlier, he was the co-founder and CEO of Schenley Park Research, a company dedicated to bringing machine learning to industry. Through his research, commercial and consulting efforts, he has worked with dozens of companies and government agencies around the world.

event_name: Turning Big Ideas Into Issue One: Launching Your Open Access Journal
description:
Find yourself in a scholarly niche that remains underrepresented in publications? Hoping to further democratize scholarly research in your field? Already managing the sharing of media that feels ready to transition to a more academic output? Generally feeling inspired to launch your own open access journal? This event is for you!
Together, we’ll review OA models, discuss guidelines for research integrity, strategize for submission management, and identify ways to increase accessibility and discoverability from the very beginning. Throughout the workshop, we will also highlight relevant services offered by the Carnegie Mellon University Libraries, including: copyright consultation, platform support, hosting, indexing, metrics, and more.
NOTE: Suggested audience includes faculty and staff who are considering launching a new academic open access journal. Students with an interest in the field of publishing more broadly might also find the material and discussion useful. No previous experience in publishing or open access is required, but this webinar will assume a basic familiarity with the academic publishing process. Please bring your questions!
Registration required: https://cmu.libcal.com/event/12871900

event_name: From the Ghetto to the Forest: Surviving the Holocaust in Belarus
location:
Noon - 1 p.m.
Posner Grand Room, Posner Hall 340
description:
Eighty-one years ago, on October 21, 1943, the Minsk ghetto was “liquidated’’—German forces rounded up the last remaining Jewish prisoners and either killed them in the surrounding forest or deported them to concentration camps further west. A group of 13 Jews, however, survived in the basement of a home in the city and saw the end of World War II. This group’s survival testifies to the brutal force of the murder campaigns in and around the ghetto.
It also demonstrates the agency Jewish children, youngsters, women and men developed in the face of marginalization, abuse and horrific violence and which enabled them to survive, in hiding or as part of so-called partisan units that gathered in the forests and swamps around Minsk and many other Belarusian cities and towns.
Anika Walke’s current research looks at the long aftermath of the Nazi genocide in Belarus. In particular, she is interested in how people remember and live with the effects and repercussions of systematic violence. She has recently taught courses on the Holocaust and the history of the Soviet Union and will join the CMU History Department in fall 2025 as the inaugural Askwith Family Professor.
Sponsored by the Department of History, The Jack Buncher Chair in Jewish Studies, and the Dietrich College of Humanities and Social Sciences.

event_name: Workforce Resilience in a Changing Technological Landscape
description:
The advent of generative AI has raised a new wave of concern about what the rapid pace of automation will mean for workers who have already made substantial investments in skills. While workers can develop skills throughout their careers, what strategies will enable them to find sustainable labor market success? How can workers start their careers to maximize long run success?
The Block Center for Technology and Society, in partnership with the Heinz College of Information Systems and Public Policy, is convening experts at the cutting edge of this research for a two-part, one-day conference. The first session is an invitation-only, academic mini-conference of paper presentations by key experts. This second session is open to the campus community, local policymakers and the public to convey the state of knowledge on this topic and to foster interactions between stakeholders and academic researchers.
Our goal is to push forward this conversation on how a skilled workforce can keep pace with the rapid technological advancement across industries. Experts will be announced soon!
Learn more and register online.

event_name: Getting Started With R and R Studio Part 1
description:
This is an introduction to R designed for participants with no R programming experience.
Part 1 of the workshop covers basic information about R syntax and the RStudio interface, including installing packages and working with vectors.
Part 2 will cover importing CSV files, working with dataframes, how to deal with categorical variables, how to add/remove rows and columns using the popular dplyr package, and how to calculate summary statistics from a dataframe. Taking Part 1 and Part 2 is encouraged, but optional.
Learners should bring a laptop and should already have installed R and RStudio on their computer.
Registration required: https://cmu.libcal.com/event/12824462

location:
5 - 6:30 p.m.
Well-being Lab (Room 104), Wellness & Meaning-Making Suite, First Floor, Highmark Center for Health, Wellness and Athletics
description:
Possible outcomes include the discovery of what value mindfulness can bring physically, emotionally, and/or mentally to each of us as individuals as well as how mindfulness might be incorporated as part of a routine in daily life to reduce stress. Those at all levels of experience with mindfulness practice are welcome. Comfortable clothing is encouraged.
Janine Carlock is a first-year writing teacher at CMU who is interested in wellness on US college campuses. She is currently working towards certification in teaching the full MBSR 8-week course.

event_name: Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives
Like, Totally Transformative: CMU in the 1980s
Data for Citizen Science and Developing Community Data
description:
There is so much data out there, but how do we know what data we need to impact our communities for the better? As more individuals work to apply their data skills developed through the academic programs, it is becoming clear that knowing where and how to use data is just as vital within a research project as it is to support community advocacy.
If you are interested in learning how to best connect data skills to community advocacy, please join us for a hands on session using local data!
This workshop is a part of CMU Libraries’ Communicating Data and Research Storytelling series.
Registration required: https://cmu.libcal.com/event/12876713

event_name: Getting Started With R and R Studio Part 2
description:
This is an introduction to R designed for participants with no R programming experience.
Part 1 of the workshop covers basic information about R syntax and the RStudio interface, including installing packages and working with vectors.
Part 2 covers importing CSV files, working with dataframes, how to deal with categorical variables, how to add/remove rows and columns using the popular dplyr package, and how to calculate summary statistics from a dataframe.
Taking Part 1 and Part 2 is encouraged, but optional.
Learners should bring a laptop and should already have installed R and RStudio on their computer.
Registration required: https://cmu.libcal.com/event/12824543

event_name: Swartz Center for Entrepreneurship CONNECTS Seminar Series
location:
12:30 - 1:30 p.m.
Swartz Center for Entrepreneurship, 3rd Level, Tepper School of Business
description:
Tailored mainly for students to help take their ideas from conception to commercialization, the seminars run throughout the academic year. Teams looking for talent and talent looking for teams can CONNECT at these events.
All CONNECTS events will be hosted in-person at the Swartz Center for Entrepreneurship, Tepper Quad, 3rd Level, from 12:30-1:30 p.m. A virtual option will also be available.
Advanced registration is required. Zoom information will be sent before the event to all registered attendees. Please note that the session will be recorded.
Fall 2024 seminar dates: Sept. 10, 11, 17, 18, 19, 24; Oct. 1, 2, 8, 9, 29, 30; Nov. 6, 7, 13.
View the series schedule details and register online at https://www.cmu.edu/swartz-center-for-entrepreneurship/events/connects/index.html.

event_name: Tips for Writing Literature Reviews Part 1
description:
In this first part of the workshop, we will cover the goals of a literature review, how to select and scope a topic, how to read papers quickly, and using library resources to find literature and take notes. While we will use examples from STEM, the tips can be applied to lit reviews in any subject area for course assignments or publication.
The second workshop in this series will focus on the actual writing of the review.
Registration required: https://cmu.libcal.com/event/12930217

Bibliometrics, or the use of tools and statistical methods to analyze published books and articles, can be a useful approach to understanding a body of knowledge and the way researchers are collaborating or publishing work on a topic. We will cover the basics of gathering a dataset for bibliometric analysis using tools like Web of Science and Scopus; provide an overview of software tools for analyzing bibliographic data; and discuss examples of bibliometric analyses across a range of disciplines. The workshop is aimed at graduate students, staff and faculty researchers, but anyone is welcome to join.
This is Part 3 of University Libraries’ Advanced and Systematized Literature Review Methods Workshop Series. You do not need to have attended previous workshops in this series.
Registration required: https://cmu.libcal.com/event/12824869
